instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: [RIP] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL>
threads.message: This board has PPBUS at 13V. It heats up when plugged in. I found a short on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL>. The CPU area and the area underneath heat up so I'm not sure if the short is the CPU itself or the circuit feeding it. <SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL> is not shorted, it measures the same as a good board. Not sure if I'm looking at the usual shorted CPU or if there might be some other move here. I attached some pre-ultrasonic pictures.

threads.title: [RIP] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL>
threads.message: what gets hot when 3.3v is injected into <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> ?

threads.title: [RIP] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No Title

It looks pretty conclusively like the CPU is shorting internally, but I can't rule out a short in the circuit causing the short inside the chip. I attached some pics of the top and bottom heating up. Ignore the red outline around the CPU, that happens with reflective metal. The glow to the left in that picture on the CPU is the area that's heating up once I send voltage through <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: [RIP] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL>
threads.message: That seems like an ope and shut case of dead CPU to me. All of my <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorts besides one have been CPU on the newer boards, it was some odd logic gate or audio IC causing it before.

threads.title: [RIP] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yeah, that's what I figured, just wanted to get a second opinion.Thanks.
